== Protests ==

=== Timeline ===
=== Timeline ===

{{main|Timeline of the 2011 Iranian protests}}
==== February 14 ====
==== February 14 ====
The date of 14 February was chosen for protests to coincide with the 25th day of Bahman,<ref name="fozoole mahaleh">{{cite news |title=ÙØ§ Ø¨Ø§ ÙÙÙ ØªÙØ§Ù Ø®ÙØ¯ Ø§Ø² Ø¬ÙØ¨Ø´ Ø³Ø¨Ø²Ø Ø¬ÙØ¨Ø´ Ø¯ÙÙÚ©Ø±Ø§Ø³Û Ù ÙØ±Ø¯ÙÛ Ø§ÛØ±Ø§ÙØ Ù¾Ø´ØªÛØ¨Ø§ÙÛ ÙÛ Ú©ÙÛÙ |author=Cyrus Parsa |url=http://www.fozoolemahaleh.com/2011/02/12/%D8%A7%D8%B2-%D8%AC%D9%86%D8%A8%D8%B4-%D9%85%D8%B1%D8%AF%D9%85%DB%8C-%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86-%D9%BE%D8%B4%D8%AA%DB%8C%D8%A8%D8%A7%D9%86%DB%8C-%D9%85%DB%8C-%DA%A9%D9%86%DB%8C%D9%85 |date=12 February 2011 |accessdate=15 February 2011}}</ref> the 11th month of the [[Persian calendar]].<ref name="CNN">{{cite news |title=U.S. State Department starts Farsi Twitter feed |author= |url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/POLITICS/02/14/state.department.twitter/?hpt=T2 |newspaper=[[CNN]] |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=14 February 2011}}</ref> The day before the protests were due to begin, opposition leaders Mousavi and Karroubi were placed under house arrest and denied access to telephones and the Internet. Their homes were blockaded and they were not allowed visitors.<ref name="UPI">{{cite news |title=Report: Thousands protest in Iran |author= |url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2011/02/14/Report-Thousands-protest-in-Iran/UPI-92661297665320/ |newspaper=[[United Press International]] |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=14 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=BBC News |title=Iran police fire tear gas at opposition rally in Tehran|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12447225 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=14 February 2011}}</ref> On 14 February 2011, thousands of protesters began to gather in a solidarity rally with Egypt and Tunisia. There was a large number of police on the streets to keep an eye on the protesters, but thousands were still able to gather together in [[Tehran]]'s [[Azadi Square]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Iran Protests: Tens Of Thousands March, Security Fires Tear Gas |author=Ali Akbar Dareini |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/02/14/iran-protests_n_822991.html |newspaper=[[The Huffington Post]] |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=14 February 2011}}</ref> The
The date of 14 February was chosen for protests to coincide with the 25th day of Bahman,<ref name="fozoole mahaleh">{{cite news |title=ÙØ§ Ø¨Ø§ ÙÙÙ ØªÙØ§Ù Ø®ÙØ¯ Ø§Ø² Ø¬ÙØ¨Ø´ Ø³Ø¨Ø²Ø Ø¬ÙØ¨Ø´ Ø¯ÙÙÚ©Ø±Ø§Ø³Û Ù ÙØ±Ø¯ÙÛ Ø§ÛØ±Ø§ÙØ Ù¾Ø´ØªÛØ¨Ø§ÙÛ ÙÛ Ú©ÙÛÙ |author=Cyrus Parsa |url=http://www.fozoolemahaleh.com/2011/02/12/%D8%A7%D8%B2-%D8%AC%D9%86%D8%A8%D8%B4-%D9%85%D8%B1%D8%AF%D9%85%DB%8C-%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86-%D9%BE%D8%B4%D8%AA%DB%8C%D8%A8%D8%A7%D9%86%DB%8C-%D9%85%DB%8C-%DA%A9%D9%86%DB%8C%D9%85 |date=12 February 2011 |accessdate=15 February 2011}}</ref> the 11th month of the [[Persian calendar]].<ref name="CNN">{{cite news |title=U.S. State Department starts Farsi Twitter feed |author= |url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/POLITICS/02/14/state.department.twitter/?hpt=T2 |newspaper=[[CNN]] |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=14 February 2011}}</ref> The day before the protests were due to begin, opposition leaders Mousavi and Karroubi were placed under house arrest and denied access to telephones and the Internet. Their homes were blockaded and they were not allowed visitors.<ref name="UPI">{{cite news |title=Report: Thousands protest in Iran |author= |url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2011/02/14/Report-Thousands-protest-in-Iran/UPI-92661297665320/ |newspaper=[[United Press International]] |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=14 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=BBC News |title=Iran police fire tear gas at opposition rally in Tehran|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12447225 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=14 February 2011}}</ref> On 14 February 2011, thousands of protesters began to gather in a solidarity rally with Egypt and Tunisia. There was a large number of police on the streets to keep an eye on the protesters, but thousands were still able to gather together in [[Tehran]]'s [[Azadi Square]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Iran Protests: Tens Of Thousands March, Security Fires Tear Gas |author=Ali Akbar Dareini |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/02/14/iran-protests_n_822991.html |newspaper=[[The Huffington Post]] |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=14 February 2011}}</ref> The
Line 68: Line 69:
There were also reports of other protester demonstrations going on in other major cities across Iran. However, coverage by journalists was thin, as the [[Ministry of Intelligence and National Security (Iran)|Ministry of Information]] had "sent a letter to foreign media offices in Tehran warning that their bureaus would be shut down and their reporters deported if they wrote "negative articles" surrounding the opposition protests." At the same time as the protests, the IRNA news agency released television reports saying that things were "completely quiet and normal". Furthermore, the Fars News Agency had released reports to the public saying that the February 20 protests would be especially violent, because the "opposition plans to shoot people."<ref name="Wall Street"/>
There were also reports of other protester demonstrations going on in other major cities across Iran. However, coverage by journalists was thin, as the [[Ministry of Intelligence and National Security (Iran)|Ministry of Information]] had "sent a letter to foreign media offices in Tehran warning that their bureaus would be shut down and their reporters deported if they wrote "negative articles" surrounding the opposition protests." At the same time as the protests, the IRNA news agency released television reports saying that things were "completely quiet and normal". Furthermore, the Fars News Agency had released reports to the public saying that the February 20 protests would be especially violent, because the "opposition plans to shoot people."<ref name="Wall Street"/>

==Arrests==
+
== Casualties ==
  +
=== Arrests ===
[[Ignacio PÃ©rez-Cambra]], the [[Consul]] of [[Spain]] in Iran, was arrested for a period of four hours during the early part of the day on 14 February. He was accused by Iranian police of going to one of the demonstrations.<ref>{{cite news |title=Detenido durante cuatro horas el cÃ³nsul de EspaÃ±a en IrÃ¡n |author=Angeles Espinosa |url=http://www.elpais.com/articulo/internacional/Detenido/durante/horas/consul/Espana/Iran/elpepuint/20110214elpepuint_10/Tes |newspaper=[[El Pais]] |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=14 February 2011}}</ref> Spain later demanded an explanation or apology from the Iranian government about the arrest of PÃ©rez-Cambra that included a "satisfactory response", threatening to call him home from Iran if one was not received. The foreign ministry already announced that it had "suspended an upcoming visit to Madrid by a senior Iranian diplomat." The UK also echoed its displeasure over the detainment of Cambra. <ref>{{cite news |title=Madrid demands Iran apologize for Spanish diplomat's arrest |author= |url=http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/politics/2011/02/15/madrid-demands-iran-apologize-spanish-diplomats-arrest/ |newspaper=[[Fox News]] |date=February 15, 2011 |accessdate=February 11, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Spain, UK protest to Iran over diplomat's detention |author=Adrian Croft |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/17/us-iran-spain-idUSTRE71G5HF20110217 |newspaper=[[Reuters]] |date=February 17, 2011 |accessdate=February 19, 2011}}</ref> Iran's [[Foreign Affairs Minister of Iran|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] [[Ali Akbar Salehi]] called the Spanish [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation (Spain)|Foreign Affairs Minister]] [[Trinidad JimÃ©nez]] on February 17 in order to apologize for the incident with Cambra, with Salehi stating that those responsible had been "unaware that they were violating the Vienna Convention", but that an investigation was underway nonetheless.<ref>{{cite news |title=Spain accepts Iranian apology for "diplomatic incident" |author= |url=http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/politics/2011/02/18/spain-accepts-iranian-apology-diplomatic-incident/ |newspaper=[[Fox News]] |date=February 18, 2011 |accessdate=February 19, 2011}}</ref>
[[Ignacio PÃ©rez-Cambra]], the [[Consul]] of [[Spain]] in Iran, was arrested for a period of four hours during the early part of the day on 14 February. He was accused by Iranian police of going to one of the demonstrations.<ref>{{cite news |title=Detenido durante cuatro horas el cÃ³nsul de EspaÃ±a en IrÃ¡n |author=Angeles Espinosa |url=http://www.elpais.com/articulo/internacional/Detenido/durante/horas/consul/Espana/Iran/elpepuint/20110214elpepuint_10/Tes |newspaper=[[El Pais]] |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=14 February 2011}}</ref> Spain later demanded an explanation or apology from the Iranian government about the arrest of PÃ©rez-Cambra that included a "satisfactory response", threatening to call him home from Iran if one was not received. The foreign ministry already announced that it had "suspended an upcoming visit to Madrid by a senior Iranian diplomat." The UK also echoed its displeasure over the detainment of Cambra. <ref>{{cite news |title=Madrid demands Iran apologize for Spanish diplomat's arrest |author= |url=http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/politics/2011/02/15/madrid-demands-iran-apologize-spanish-diplomats-arrest/ |newspaper=[[Fox News]] |date=February 15, 2011 |accessdate=February 11, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Spain, UK protest to Iran over diplomat's detention |author=Adrian Croft |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/17/us-iran-spain-idUSTRE71G5HF20110217 |newspaper=[[Reuters]] |date=February 17, 2011 |accessdate=February 19, 2011}}</ref> Iran's [[Foreign Affairs Minister of Iran|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] [[Ali Akbar Salehi]] called the Spanish [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation (Spain)|Foreign Affairs Minister]] [[Trinidad JimÃ©nez]] on February 17 in order to apologize for the incident with Cambra, with Salehi stating that those responsible had been "unaware that they were violating the Vienna Convention", but that an investigation was underway nonetheless.<ref>{{cite news |title=Spain accepts Iranian apology for "diplomatic incident" |author= |url=http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/politics/2011/02/18/spain-accepts-iranian-apology-diplomatic-incident/ |newspaper=[[Fox News]] |date=February 18, 2011 |accessdate=February 19, 2011}}</ref>
Line 77: Line 78:
The official number of protesters arrested is relayed as 150 by the government, though the opposition claims that the numbers are far higher, around 1,500.<ref>{{cite news |title=Iranâs Leader Derides Protests; Lawmakers Urge Death for Opposition Leaders |author=Neil MacFarquhar |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/16/world/middleeast/16iran.html?src=mv |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=February 15, 2011 |accessdate=February 15, 2011}}</ref>
The official number of protesters arrested is relayed as 150 by the government, though the opposition claims that the numbers are far higher, around 1,500.<ref>{{cite news |title=Iranâs Leader Derides Protests; Lawmakers Urge Death for Opposition Leaders |author=Neil MacFarquhar |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/16/world/middleeast/16iran.html?src=mv |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=February 15, 2011 |accessdate=February 15, 2011}}</ref>

==Deaths==
+
=== Deaths ===
The human rights organization [[HRANA]]'s website reported one person had died after riot police opened fire at protesters near Tohid Square in Tehran.<ref name="Guardian">{{cite news |title=Iran protests see reinvigorated activists take to the streets in thousands |author=Saeed Kamali Dehghan |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/14/iran-protests-reinvigorated-activists |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date14 February 2011 |accessdate=14 February 2011}}</ref> According to [[Kazem Jalali]], one of the injured protesters also died later in the day on February 14.<ref name="Nowhere"></ref>
The human rights organization [[HRANA]]'s website reported one person had died after riot police opened fire at protesters near Tohid Square in Tehran.<ref name="Guardian">{{cite news |title=Iran protests see reinvigorated activists take to the streets in thousands |author=Saeed Kamali Dehghan |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/14/iran-protests-reinvigorated-activists |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date14 February 2011 |accessdate=14 February 2011}}</ref> According to [[Kazem Jalali]], one of the injured protesters also died later in the day on February 14.<ref name="Nowhere"></ref>
Line 88: Line 89:
==Response==
==Response==
===Domestic===
===Domestic===
  +
{{main|Domestic responses to the 2011 Iranian protests}}
All forms of Iranian media were banned from covering the protests, though the demonstrators were still able to release information by utilizing social media like [[Facebook]] and [[Twitter]].<ref name="AFP"/> In addition, foreign media was banned from covering the events.<ref name="Forbes"/> Beginning February 10th, in anticipation of protests in Iran, the Iranian government began censoring "pro-opposition websites and other electronic media". The keyword "Bahman", which is the current month in the Persian calender, was also "added to the list of blocked keywords for messages on mobile phones in an attempt to reduce calls for protests on a specific day." This censorship has resulted in slowed internet connection speed in many major cities of Iran.<ref>{{cite news |title=Faced with protests, Iran strengthens censorship |author= |url=http://www.myfoxboston.com/dpp/news/international/faced-with-protests-iran-strengthens-censorship-25-ncx-20110215 |newspaper=[[WFXT]] |date=February 15, 2011 |accessdate=February 15, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Iran Tries Internet Censorship, Execution As Protesters Demand Democracy |author=Nitasha Tiku |url=http://nymag.com/daily/intel/2011/02/iran_tries_internet_censorship.html |newspaper=[[New York Magazine]] |date=February 15, 2011 |accessdate=February 15, 2011}}</ref>
All forms of Iranian media were banned from covering the protests, though the demonstrators were still able to release information by utilizing social media like [[Facebook]] and [[Twitter]].<ref name="AFP"/> In addition, foreign media was banned from covering the events.<ref name="Forbes"/> Beginning February 10th, in anticipation of protests in Iran, the Iranian government began censoring "pro-opposition websites and other electronic media". The keyword "Bahman", which is the current month in the Persian calender, was also "added to the list of blocked keywords for messages on mobile phones in an attempt to reduce calls for protests on a specific day." This censorship has resulted in slowed internet connection speed in many major cities of Iran.<ref>{{cite news |title=Faced with protests, Iran strengthens censorship |author= |url=http://www.myfoxboston.com/dpp/news/international/faced-with-protests-iran-strengthens-censorship-25-ncx-20110215 |newspaper=[[WFXT]] |date=February 15, 2011 |accessdate=February 15, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Iran Tries Internet Censorship, Execution As Protesters Demand Democracy |author=Nitasha Tiku |url=http://nymag.com/daily/intel/2011/02/iran_tries_internet_censorship.html |newspaper=[[New York Magazine]] |date=February 15, 2011 |accessdate=February 15, 2011}}</ref>
Line 108: Line 110:
The Islamic Propagation Coordination Council called for a rally on February 18, 2011, in order to "show anger at what it calls the 'crimes' of 'seditionist' leaders and their rebel allies." As a result, before and after Friday prayer, thousands of pro-government demonstrators poured to the streets of major cities to demonstrate their support and demand prosecution of Mousavi, Karroubi and Khatami. <ref name="VOA">{{cite news |title=Iranian Govt. Calls for Friday Rally to Show 'Hatred' for Opposition |author= |url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Clashes-Breakout-at-Memorial-for-Protest-Victim-in-Iran-116298439.html |newspaper=[[Voice of America]] |date=February 16, 2011 |accessdate=February 16, 2011}}</ref>
The Islamic Propagation Coordination Council called for a rally on February 18, 2011, in order to "show anger at what it calls the 'crimes' of 'seditionist' leaders and their rebel allies." As a result, before and after Friday prayer, thousands of pro-government demonstrators poured to the streets of major cities to demonstrate their support and demand prosecution of Mousavi, Karroubi and Khatami. <ref name="VOA">{{cite news |title=Iranian Govt. Calls for Friday Rally to Show 'Hatred' for Opposition |author= |url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Clashes-Breakout-at-Memorial-for-Protest-Victim-in-Iran-116298439.html |newspaper=[[Voice of America]] |date=February 16, 2011 |accessdate=February 16, 2011}}</ref>
â
===International===
+
=== International ===
â
+
{{Main|International reactions to 2011 Iranian protests}}
====Non-governmental organizations====
====Non-governmental organizations====
The police crackdown on protesters led [[Amnesty International]] to denounce Iranian authorities. They released a statement saying, "Iranians have a right to gather to peacefully express their support for the people of Egypt and Tunisia."<ref>{{cite news |title=Iran Protest Crackdown Condemned |author= |url=http://www.amnesty.org/en/news-and-updates/iran-protest-crackdown-condemned-2011-02-14 |newspaper=[[Amnesty International]] |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=14 February 2011}}</ref>
The police crackdown on protesters led [[Amnesty International]] to denounce Iranian authorities. They released a statement saying, "Iranians have a right to gather to peacefully express their support for the people of Egypt and Tunisia."<ref>{{cite news |title=Iran Protest Crackdown Condemned |author= |url=http://www.amnesty.org/en/news-and-updates/iran-protest-crackdown-condemned-2011-02-14 |newspaper=[[Amnesty International]] |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=14 February 2011}}</ref>
